captions.text: BRADY HARAN: We did a video.

I'd done it some time ago
about Mersenne primes.

And offhandedly, just
off the cuff, I said
that 1 wasn't a prime.

Now, if I'm honest, we
don't say 1 is prime.

There's a special
reason for that.

And we noticed that some people
in the comments said,

well, I think I've heard of this
before, but why is that?
Why isn't 1 a prime?
So what is a prime number?
Let's think of the definition.

You probably know
the definition.

A prime number is a number that
can only be divided by 1
and itself.

So the prime numbers are
2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13.
You know these numbers.

So it sounds like 1 should
be a prime number, right?

It fits the definition
of the prime number.

You can divide by 1, and
you can divide by
itself, which is 1.

And historically, it was
considered a prime number.

So if you're thinking, hmm, it
sounds like it should be.

Well, that's what they
used to think.

That's what mathematicians
used to think as well.

But in the end, they
had to exclude it
from the prime numbers.

Oh poor old 1, 1 is the
loneliest number, the

loneliest number
you'll ever do.
So it's excluded for a reason.

There's a really important
theorem in mathematics.

It's called the Fundamental
Theorem of Arithmetic.

Now, it says that every positive
whole number can be

written as a product by
multiplying prime numbers.
So here it is.

I didn't want to write it
out, so here it is.

Every positive whole number, or
integer, if you like, can

be written as a unique
product of primes.

So you can tell this is an
important theorem because it
has a name.

And you can tell it's a very
important theorem because it
has a pompous name.

So what this means is prime
numbers are our atoms, like
atoms in chemistry.

They can be used to make other
numbers by multiplying these
primes together.

So for example, 15
is 3 times 5.
3 and 5 are prime.

And you can make 15 from
multiplying primes together.

But there's a very important
word here in this theorem.
Look at this word, unique.

Now that's not just there
for decoration.

Every word is important,
unique.
It has to be a unique product.
There's only one way to do it.

Now we know, of course, that
15 is also 5 times 3.

We don't mind that,
that's allowed.
We don't mind that.

What we don't like is that
15 is 1 times 3 times 5.

Not only that, but it's also
1 times 1 times 3 times 5.

And it's 1 times 1 times 1 times
3 times 5, and so on.

If 1 was a prime, then we
wouldn't have a unique way of

writing 15 as a product
of prime numbers.

So what this meant was, when
they used to think it was
prime, they had to keep
excluding 1 from your theorems.

You would have to keep saying,
take all the prime numbers,
except for 1.

And we just got tired
of doing that.

So we just decided to exclude 1
from our definition of prime
to begin with.
So 1 isn't a prime number.

It isn't considered a composite
number, where you

make the other numbers
from primes.

No, it has a category all of
its own, where it sits, all
lonely by itself.

MALE SPEAKER: But why does
this mean 1's not prime?

Maybe it's just a
stupid theorem.
Maybe the theorem's no good.

Why does the theorem
beat number 1 out?
BRADY HARAN: We have a choice.

We have a choice to include
it in that category
if we wanted to.

Prime's just a word, it's
just a category.

And it's more useful for us to
say, take this list, which is
the list of all the primes.
And it doesn't have 1 on it.

It's more useful to say,
take this list.

And that list is 2, 3, 5,
7, 11, blah, blah, blah.

MALE SPEAKER: Looking at that
theorem, doesn't that mean

that 1 isn't a whole number
because 1, surely 1 can't be

made as a unique product
of primes?
BRADY HARAN: OK.
Well, let's have a look.
Let's take--
I'll start with 16.

16 is a product of primes
because it's 2 times 2
times 2 times 2.
It's four primes.
8 is a product of primes.
It's 2 times 2 times 2.

So I've just divided
by 2 there.
4 is a product of two primes.

The number 2, the prime number
2, is a product of just one
prime number.

And then if I divide by 2 again,
I get 1, which is the
product of zero prime numbers.
It's called an empty product.

So we've got a product of 4
primes, 3 primes, 2 primes,

continue the pattern, 1
prime, and 0 primes.
It's 1, and it's not 0.

It's 1, it's called
an empty product.

Oh, that won't be it
for the number 1.

We'll be hearing from the number
1 again soon, I'm sure.

everything is 1^(infinity) times everything, if and only if, there is no 
such thing a a unique product of primes. if that is false or if that is 
true, then the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic is wrong. The Fundamental 
Theorem of Arithmetic is true, if and only if, false does not exist. Now 
you have two options, the theorem is false, or the universe is a paradox, 
but they cannot be both. If the universe is a paradox and the theorem is 
false, then that in itself would also be a paradox, and therefore you would 
have a paradox in a paradox. If a paradox is in a paradox, then you would 
have a paradox*4 since it is a paradox for a paradox to exist, so then you 
would go down the path unti you have a paradox*infinity, now, what is the 
better choice now? a infinite paradox, or a non-paradox?
so 1 is a prime number, and that theorem is wrong.﻿

comments.author: AllExpensesPayed

comments.text:
+AllExpensesPayed Yeah, it shouldn't make sense why a product of nothing is 
equal to 1, but you can see it with the following:


30 = 2 x 3 x 5
= product(2, 3, 5)
= product(2, 3) x 5
= product(2) x 3 x 5
= product() x 2 x 3 x 5 = 30


So product() = 1. This isn't a proof, but it's not something mathematicians 
just made up because they want it to be true :P

comments.author: 2010RSHACKS

comments.text:
1 is not a prime number. (WHAT?) #unlearning  #math

I came across this while reading a GRE review book. I thought it was a typo 
at first, but it turns out that it's true. I find this happens more and 
more now, that adulthood seems to consist of unlearning things you've 
learned before.

In this case, I distinctly remember learning in grade school that 1 was a 
prime number. Had I just been taught wrong? Well, not really, but maybe it 
took a while for the updated information to reach math teachers in the 
Philippines. 1 was historically considered a prime number. According to 
Wikipedia, the last professional mathematician to consider 1 a prime number 
was Henri Lebesgue, and he died in 1941. :/﻿

comments.author: Trip75

comments.text:
We use a or an depending on the first *sound* of the next word.  

"Unique," although starting with a vowel, actually begins with a consonant 
sound in its pronunciation, so it is properly written as "a unique" rather 
than "an unique."  

The opposite situation can be seen with words like "hour."  Even though 
"hour" begins with a consonant, the pronunciation begins with a vowel 
sound, and so one would say "an hour" rather than "a hour."

Although there are sometimes exceptions to this rule.  "A historical" and 
"an historical" are often both accepted.

http://english.stackexchange.com/questions/152/when-should-i-use-a-vs-an

comments.text:
If "every positive whole number can be written as a unique product of 
primes" - what about prime numbers themselves? They are positive whole 
numbers, and they can only be written as a unique (integer) product of 
themselves and one. If one isn't prime, then they can't be written as "a 
unique product of *primes*," but rather as a unique product of *a prime* 
and one.﻿

comments.text:
+MuffinsAPlenty Thanks for the explanation.

Does the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic then need to be restated as 
well? After all, the term "primes" *is* plural, and the distinction between 
unity and plurality seems to be a rather important one ... or should we 
simply read it to mean (if it were fully expounded) "one or more primes?"
comments.author: A. Joe

comments.text:
For this theorem, we are using a generalized notion of "product." 
 Technically, a product is the result of multiplying *two* numbers 
together.  No less, but no more either.  Obviously, seeing the statement of 
the theorem, this is not the notion of product we are using.  (Think: 12 = 
2*2*3, a product of 3 primes.)

So we generalize the notion of product to be for any finite set of natural 
numbers (this works well because of the commutative and associative 
properties of multiplication).  So this allows us to multiply more than 2 
numbers together at a time, but we also extend the definition in the other 
way.  A product of one number is that number itself, and a product of zero 
numbers (the empty product) is 1.

So 2 = 2 is writing 2 as a product of primes.  It is a unary product, 
having just one input.

comments.text:
+Numberphile I think there is an easier way to describe why 1 isn't a prim 
number.

There are 4 categories of Numbers:
0: Can't be divided by any Number to create something else then 0, and 0 
doesn’t count
1: Can only be divided by 1 Number, which is 1 by the way
Prim Numbers: Can only be divided by 2 Numbers
Any Other Number: Can be divided by 3 and more Numbers, but there is an 
finite amount of Numbers
 
There are other “special” Numbers how would maybe also need an own 
category, like Infinity, because I think Infinity can theoretically be 
divided by every Number. Also I don't know if negativ Numbers count as 
well, but I don't think so.

So 1 is clearly not a prime becose it has only 1 factor. With other words 
the definicion of prims is wrong, just a little tiny bit. New difinition: A 
prim Number is a Number that can exactly be divided by 2 diffrent factors. 
Not more, not less.﻿

comments.author: MoveLookListen

comments.text:
Another way to state the FTA is as follows:

"Let P be the set of prime numbers. Then for any positive whole number N 
there is a unique subset K of P such that N is the product of the elements 
of K."

The set of primes such that 1 is the product of its elements is empty, and 
the empty set is a subset of any set, including P.﻿

0 is a number.  It is another category of number.  It is a "zero divisor."

generally consider zero to be a "zero divisor" (except in the 0 ring).

comments.author: MrAquaX

comments.text:
A example illustrating that the empty product = 1 (using 2, 3, 5 and 7 as 
sample multipliers):

product(2, 3, 5, 7)
= product(2, 3, 5) x 7
= product(2, 3) x 5 x 7
= product(2) x 3 x 5 x 7
= product() x 2 x 3 x 5 x 7

... so the remaining empty product on the left must = 1.

The empty sum can be shown to be zero by similar means.﻿

comments.author: Banjo

comments.text:
+kowalski2015 Most definitions of prime you see will specifically exclude 1 
from the definition.  

For example, Wikipedia gives this definition:
"A prime number (or a prime) is a natural number greater than 1 that has no 
positive divisors other than 1 and itself."

Wolfram MathWorld gives this definition:
"A prime number (or prime integer, often simply called a "prime" for short) 
is a positive integer p>1 that has no positive integer divisors other than 
1 and p itself. (More concisely, a prime number p is a positive integer 
having exactly one positive divisor other than 1.)"

And even if you're dealing with abstractions of the concept of prime in 
subjects like abstract algebra, units are specifically excluded from the 
definition of a prime (in any commutative ring where 1 exists, 1 is a unit, 
and so is excluded from the definition of prime).  Wikipedia gives this 
definition for a prime element of a commutative ring:
"An element p of a commutative ring R is said to be prime if it is not zero 
or a unit and whenever p divides ab for some a and b in R, then p divides a 
or p divides b."
comments.author: MuffinsAPlenty

comments.text:
Why is 1 the result of an empty product? Here's why:

2^3 = 2x2x2 = 8
2^2 = 2x2 = 4
2^1 = 2 = 2
2^0 = __ = 1
3^0 = __ = 1
n^0 = __ = 1 (any number multiplied by itself 0 times is always 1 -- that 
was just decided some time, and I'm sure it's since been thoroughly proven, 
however counter intuitive it may be).

I wish they included the P^0 part in the video, because that would have 
helped clear up why the empty product is 1.

Even 0 can be excluded by this definition, because while in theory it can 
be divided by itself (0/0 = 0) and 1 (0/1 = 0), there is no product of 
primes that results in 0, even the empty product stops at 1.﻿

comments.text:
+athox n^1 "must" also be a valid product is just circular--I'm questioning 
whether it should be included.

I think your digression proves my point.  I'm saying "n^1" is not a 
product.  Let's get back to that in a moment.  You say, not only is n^1 a 
product, but so is n^0.

If you count n^0 as a product, you have broken the theorem.  Because then 
1=5^0, 1=10^0, 1=453235^0, etc.  So you MUST exclude n^0--n^0 cannot be a 
"product" for the purposes of this definition.

Why are you excluding n^0 as a "product," but then objecting to me wanting 
to exclude n^1 as a "product"?  You've lost whatever principle you were 
going by.

The point of this theorem, as I understand it, is that there are two kinds 
of whole numbers:  prime numbers and composite numbers.  The point is that 
there is no number that is NOT either prime or composite.  By not saying 
every number is either prime or the product of primes, it seems to me you 
lose the entire point of the theorem.

I think a better explanation is that saying "a prime number is a product of 
itself" is trivial, so it's unimportant either way.  Stating it as it is in 
the video is more concise at the loss perhaps of a little more insight into 
its point; saying "either prime itself or a product" is more words, hence 
perhaps less clear even though perhaps it points more to the meaning of the 
theorem.  But either way, the statement that a prime is a product of itself 
is trivial, so it is the author's choice.

As I said in my original post, I would have chosen the more words with the 
deeper meaning.
comments.author: greg55666

comments.text:
I think it kinda goes without saying seeing as the *definition* of primes 
is that they are explicitly not made up of a product of any two other 
numbers except themselves and 1. Seeing as the theorem includes the use of

needing to comply with its stated definition.
comments.author: Capi Swift

comments.text:
+greg55666 Why shouldn't prime numbers be included? The prime numbers have 
a prime product too.

You can agree that n^2 is the same as n x n, right? As in, n multiplied by 
itself twice.

Equally, n multiplied by itself once, must also be a valid product, namely 
n.

n = n^1 = n

See? You cannot get past the n^1 as being a valid multiplication, even if 
it only has one factor.

-------

Digression:

Also, n multiplied by itself never, is also a valid product. Which is why 
n^0 = 1 has no factors, prime or otherwise... If you include 1 in primes 
then you can do 1^1 = 1, but then we're back to intentionally excluding it 
for practical purposes.

seen, I'm saying, I do not doubt James has some justification for writing 
it as he did.)

comments.author: Alex B

comments.text:
The theorem is not complete. It should read "every positive whole number 
can be written as a unique product of primes, *regardless the arrangment of 
those primes*".

Meaning that 6 = 2x3 = 3x2 is the same product, only the order is changed. 
6 = 1x2x3 would break this theorem, but 1 is not a prime.

And 4 = 2x2, yes ! The theorem does not forbid the primes to be used more 
than once in the product. Your assertion "a product consists of 2 or more 
numbers" is wrong. A product are numbers multiplicating together, so there 
can be only one number, 3 numbers, 10, or even 0 number, and they might be 
equal or not.

More precisely, for a given number N , you can choose *one and only one* 
list of n numbers (p_1,p_2,....,p_n) and *one* list of power 
(a_1,a_2,...,a_n), such as:
- the 'p' numbers are different primes number, arranged from the lowest to 
the largest. (which gives an order and prevent the re-arrangment)
- the powers 'a' are positive ( > 1 ) (which prevent the x^0 which is equal 
to one and would break the unicity)
- you have :   N  =  productOfEvery( p_i ^ a_i ) , i going from 1 to n.

n can be 0, then for 1 , the list of numbers p and a are empty, and  1 is 
the product of the 'empty set'.

The consequence of this is that for every number, the number 'n' of prime 
factors is set, and always exist (the list of factors cannot be infinite)
comments.author: Olivier Le Tiec

divisors," then, according to this definition, 1 cannot be a prime number, 
because it has only one divisor. Problem solved.﻿
comments.author: Socrates Alexander

comments.text: *counting number
comments.author: Magor CS

comments.text: So one and zero are neither prime nor composite. ﻿

comments.author: MrSamwise25

comments.author: Jaysonfred

comments.text:
We (science) count 2 as a prime number. However there is a 2 contradiction:
The definition of primes is: The prime number is the number that can only 
be divided by 1 and itself.
On the other hand as per “Fundamental theorem of arithmetic”-  Every 
positive whole number can be written as a unique product of primes.  How 2 
could be written as a product?  The only way is 2*1. According the 
definition  2 is a prime but as per the theorem is not because by default 1 
is not a prime number.
So in this case either 1 is a prime or 2 is not. What is the explanation?﻿
comments.author: Prime numbers

comments.text:
+Prime numbers He explains this. All the primes are made of themselves. 2 
factored is 2; there is no requirement for there to be two factors.
comments.author: Allan Floyd

comments.text:
+Prime numbers A product doesn't have to contain more than one factor. You 
could just say that you have the factor 2 and then you don't multiply it 
with anything, and that gives you the product 2. You can even have no 
factors at all and still say that you have a product, which then becomes 
the empty product which he talks about at the end of the video, which is 
defined as 1.
comments.author: MasterOfTheChainsaw

comments.text:
+Jakromha I think the definition of "can be divided by" means that the 
product of the division has to be a positive whole number. Dividing by -1 
gives us a negative whole number so it doesn't count. I guess you could 
create a whole new category of "super primes" or something like that which 
contains also divisions by -1, but that would be something else.
comments.author: MasterOfTheChainsaw

comments.text:
+Prime numbers Actually, the only number that is prime is -1. 5 for 
example, can be divided by 1, itself, but also -1 and -itself.Real 
definition I think should be:
A number that can be devided by exactly four whole numbers.
comments.author: Jakromha

comments.text:
This problem is true for ever prime number. I believe it's easier to 
consider 1 a prime number, especially since, by prime definition, it is 
prime.
comments.author: A Rob
